title: Review: Jay Z & Kanye West – Watch The Throne
content:
With combined worldwide album sales exceeding 75 million, several dozen entries in the Billboard Top 100, and the ability to sell out shows in every country across the globe; there’s no doubting the success of Jay-Z and Kanye West.

Having both well and truly cemented their names amongst the hip-hop greats, the announcement of a collaboration record was met with sheer adulation. Whilst Jay-Z’s most recent attempt The Blueprint III was somewhat underwhelming and out of keeping with his discerning high standards, the same cannot be said of Kanye West, whose My Beautiful Dark Twisted Fantasy proved to have all the makings of a career defining record. So with Watch The Throne, not only is it intriguing to witness two artists potentially at opposite ends of their creative careers, but also to experience the competitive friction hopefully stimulated by the clash of two confident, talented musicians.

Having previously worked together on each others tracks, including College Dropout highlight Never Let Me Go and a fantastic remix of Diamonds From Sierra Leone that far surpassed the original version, expectations were rightly sky high. From merely glancing down the tracklisting, the first point of note that jumps out is the noticeable lack of guest appearances. Aside from a couple of sleazy R’nB moments from Frank Ocean, an Otis Redding sample, a slot from Mr Hudson and a stereotypically soulful chorus from Beyonce; Watch Your Throne is almost entirely focused on the Rockefella rappers. A courageous decision, especially when considered alongside the knowledge that a phenomenal total of thirty other artists featured on the respective rappers most recent LP’s. Not only does this ensure that there is no chance of secondary acts stealing the show (see Nicki Minaj on Monster and J.Cole on A Star Is Born), but also that the focal point is most definitely on the West and Carter.

Much like on My Beautiful Dark Twisted Fantasy, the premier track on this record provides a platform for one of R’n’B’s finest young talents, with OFWGKTA’s Frank Ocean stepping up to the plate. The beats are far more pronounced and dare I say it heavier, than on previous output from either performer. The sassy bass section on No Church In The Wild being a fantastic example of this, providing a stark contrast to Ocean’s slick vocals. Having years of experience under their belts has clearly aided the production on Watch The Throne, which is smooth and exemplary throughout; whilst remaining sonically varied.

There are few rappers who can rival the tawdry delivery of West or the renowned drawl of Jay-Z, however when West tries his hand at singing the results are far less consistent, as found on the Beyonce featuring Lift Off, where her vocal sections are by far the highlight of the track. However on the latter half of Niggas In Paris, Kanye’s singing is vastly improved and fitting to the theme of the track, showing there are benefits of having such a malleable style. Being two of the voices of our generation both in recognition and lyrical content, finding a track like Murder To Excellence on the record was a given. Dark and knowingly enlightened, Kanye sits in the driving seat for the majority of the song; ‘Is it genocide? Cause I can still hear his mama cry, know the family traumatized, shots left holes in his face about pirranha-sized’, harrowing, albeit slightly contrived. Watch The Throne has Dilla vibes littered throughout the record, from the spliced samples of Otis to the frequent instrumental breakdowns, it’s clear that West and Jay-Z are attempting to raise the bar through creating prolific and munificent beats. In an age when almost anyone can produce music, the pressure to push proverbial boundaries is building upon those at the height of their game, and Watch The Throne certainly doesn’t disappoint in that sense.

First single proper Otis is based around a rather repetitive Redding sample which nearly proves overly dominating and the flow threatens to become lost beneath it all. Where Watch The Throne slips up is on the lyricism from West and Jay-Z, which at times is lethargic and uninspired; far befitting the quality of the tracks. For two artists who are so boisterously outspoken both on their music and in real life, they say little of any worth and certainly nothing haughtily profound. Album highlight New Day is one of the exceptions in so far as the lyrical content, yet this is no surprise as the tempo is slower and the beat less pronounced, allowing the duo to breath life into the track.

Otis feat. Otis Redding by watchthethrone

Having collaborated in the past to produce such iconic hip hop tracks, it’s disappointing to find the two in such a seemingly discouraged mood. The competitive feel to the Diamonds From Sierra Leone Remix was undoubtedly what provided the invigorating spark that allowed the track to excel, however this spirit is truly lacking on Watch The Throne. There’s an underlying feeling that perhaps the two rested on their laurels when it comes to the delivery and content of the lyrics, and instead concluded that the beats and production were imperative to the success of the record. As an entirety, it’s far from a disaster, yet it fails to soar to the dizzy heights previously experienced by the duo and that so justifiably fortified Kanye West and Jay-Z amongst the hip hop greats.
